key_points: Drivers in the Southeast U.S. are ignoring government pleas not to hoard fuel amidst a major pipeline shutdown.
Lines formed at gas stations, with many running out of fuel due to increased demand.
Fistfights and altercations over gasoline were reported in several locations.
Nearly 60% of gas stations in metro Atlanta, and over 70% in Charlotte, Raleigh, and Pensacola were without gas.
The average national gasoline price rose to above $3.00 a gallon, the highest since October 2014.
The Colonial Pipeline shutdown, caused by a ransomware hack, heavily affects the Southeast and Mid-Atlantic.
The Biden administration warned against hoarding and filling plastic bags with fuel.
Georgia Governor Brian Kemp temporarily suspended gas taxes to ease price hikes.
Some individuals, disregarding official advice, are going to lengths to stockpile fuel.
Industry representatives plead with drivers to stay calm and not exacerbate the situation by hoarding.
spokespersons: Cherie Thomas (Manager, Exxon Mobil station, Chapel Hill, North Carolina)
Rob Underwood (President, Energy Marketers of America)
